sections.name: Classification of Numbers
sections.theory:
Numbers are classified into:
• Natural Numbers (N): 1, 2, 3, 4... (Counting numbers)
• Whole Numbers (W): 0, 1, 2, 3... (Natural + Zero)
• Integers (Z): ...-3, -2, -1, 0, 1, 2, 3...
• Rational (Q): Can be expressed as p/q where q≠0. Ex: 1/2, 0.5, 0.333..., 3
• Irrational: Cannot be expressed as p/q. Non-terminating non-recurring decimals. Ex: √2, π, e
• Real Numbers: All rational + irrational
• Prime: Exactly 2 factors (1 and itself). Ex: 2,3,5,7,11...
• Composite: More than 2 factors. Ex: 4,6,8,9...
• Even: Divisible by 2. Ends in 0,2,4,6,8
• Odd: Not divisible by 2. Ends in 1,3,5,7,9
• Co-prime: Two numbers whose HCF is 1. Ex: (8,15), (9,16)
sections.example:
Q: Find the sum of first 100 natural numbers.

Solution:
Using formula: Sum = n(n+1)/2
n = 100
Sum = 100(100+1)/2
Sum = 100 × 101/2
Sum = 10100/2
Sum = 5050

Answer: 5050
sections.formula:
Sum of first n natural numbers = n(n+1)/2
Sum of first n odd numbers = n²
Sum of first n even numbers = n(n+1)
Sum of squares: 1² + 2² + ... + n² = n(n+1)(2n+1)/6
Sum of cubes: 1³ + 2³ + ... + n³ = [n(n+1)/2]²
sections.shortcut:
• First 10 naturals sum = 55 (memorize)
• First 100 naturals sum = 5050 (memorize)
• Sum of n odd = n² (quick mental calc)
• 2 is the only even prime number
• 1 is neither prime nor composite

sections.name: Divisibility Rules
sections.theory:
Quick tests to check divisibility without actual division:
• Divisible by 2: Last digit is 0, 2, 4, 6, or 8
• Divisible by 3: Sum of digits is divisible by 3
• Divisible by 4: Last 2 digits form number divisible by 4
• Divisible by 5: Last digit is 0 or 5
• Divisible by 6: Divisible by both 2 AND 3
• Divisible by 8: Last 3 digits form number divisible by 8
• Divisible by 9: Sum of digits is divisible by 9
• Divisible by 10: Last digit is 0
• Divisible by 11: Difference between (sum of digits at odd places) and (sum of digits at even places) is 0 or divisible by 11
• Divisible by 12: Divisible by both 3 AND 4
sections.example:
Q: Check if 5432178 is divisible by 9.

Solution:
Sum of digits = 5+4+3+2+1+7+8 = 30
Check if 30 is divisible by 9:
30 ÷ 9 = 3 remainder 3
Since 30 is NOT divisible by 9,
5432178 is NOT divisible by 9.

Alternate: Remainder when divided by 9 = Remainder of sum
Remainder = 30 mod 9 = 3

Answer: Not divisible (Remainder 3)
sections.formula:
Divisibility by 7: Double the last digit, subtract from remaining number. Repeat until single/double digit.
Divisibility by 13: Multiply last digit by 4, add to remaining number. If result divisible, original is divisible.
Divisibility by 11: |Sum(odd position) - Sum(even position)| = 0 or 11k
sections.shortcut:
• Number divisible by 6, 12, 15, 18 implies divisibility by their factors
• Sum of digits trick works for 3 and 9 ONLY
• Remainder when divided by 9 = Remainder of digit sum divided by 9
• A number 'abcabc' (like 123123) is ALWAYS divisible by 7, 11, and 13

sections.name: Unit Digit & Cyclicity
sections.theory:
The unit (last) digit of x^n follows a cyclic pattern:

Cycle Length 1 (Constant):
• 0^n always ends in 0
• 1^n always ends in 1
• 5^n always ends in 5
• 6^n always ends in 6

Cycle Length 2:
• 4: Pattern 4, 6, 4, 6...
• 9: Pattern 9, 1, 9, 1...

Cycle Length 4 (Most Common):
• 2: Pattern 2, 4, 8, 6, 2, 4, 8, 6...
• 3: Pattern 3, 9, 7, 1, 3, 9, 7, 1...
• 7: Pattern 7, 9, 3, 1, 7, 9, 3, 1...
• 8: Pattern 8, 4, 2, 6, 8, 4, 2, 6...

Method: Divide power by cycle length, use remainder to find position in cycle.
sections.example:
Q: Find the unit digit of 7^2023.

Solution:
Base ends in 7.
Cycle for 7: 7, 9, 3, 1 (length 4)

Step 1: Divide power by cycle length
2023 ÷ 4 = 505 remainder 3

Step 2: Remainder determines position
Remainder = 3
Position 3 in cycle: 7, 9, 3

Unit digit = 3

Alternate approach:
7^1 = 7
7^2 = 49 (unit digit 9)
7^3 = 343 (unit digit 3)
7^4 = 2401 (unit digit 1)
Pattern repeats every 4.

Answer: Unit digit is 3
sections.formula:
Unit digit of (a × b) = Unit digit of [UD(a) × UD(b)]
Unit digit of (a + b) = Unit digit of [UD(a) + UD(b)]
Unit digit of (a - b) = Unit digit of [UD(a) - UD(b)]
sections.shortcut:
• Any even number raised to ANY power ≥2 gives even unit digit
• Odd^Odd = Odd, Odd^Even = Odd (unit digit stays odd type)
• 5 × Any = ends in 0 or 5
• For bases ending in 2,3,7,8: Divide power by 4
• For bases ending in 4,9: Divide power by 2
• Memorize: 2^10 = 1024, so unit digit of 2^10k = 4 always

sections.name: Tests of Divisibility - Advanced
sections.theory:
For larger divisors:

Divisibility by 7:
Method 1: Double last digit, subtract from rest. Repeat.
Example: 203 → 20 - 2(3) = 20 - 6 = 14 (divisible)

Divisibility by 13:
Method: Multiply last digit by 4, add to rest. Repeat.

Divisibility by 17:
Method: Multiply last digit by 5, subtract from rest.

Divisibility by 19:
Method: Multiply last digit by 2, add to rest.

Divisibility by combined numbers:
• Divisible by 24: Divisible by 3 AND 8
• Divisible by 36: Divisible by 4 AND 9
• Divisible by 72: Divisible by 8 AND 9
sections.example:
Q: Check if 343 is divisible by 7.

Solution (Method 1):
Double last digit: 2 × 3 = 6
Subtract from remaining: 34 - 6 = 28
28 is divisible by 7 ✓
Therefore, 343 is divisible by 7.

Verification: 343 ÷ 7 = 49

Answer: Yes, divisible by 7
sections.formula:
Divisibility test formula:
For divisor d, if N = 10a + b, then
N ≡ (m×b + a) (mod d)
where m is chosen multiplier for that divisor
sections.shortcut:
• For 7: If confused, just divide and check
• Numbers like 111, 222, 333... are divisible by 3 and 37
• Numbers with all same digits (111, 7777) → sum of digits = digit × count

sections.name: Factorial & Trailing Zeros
sections.theory:
n! = n × (n-1) × (n-2) × ... × 2 × 1
0! = 1 (by definition)
1! = 1

Trailing Zeros in n!:
Come from pairs of (2 × 5).
Since 2s are abundant, count number of 5s.

Formula: [n/5] + [n/25] + [n/125] + [n/625]...
where [x] = floor(x)
sections.example:
Q: How many trailing zeros in 100!?

Solution:
Count multiples of 5, 25, 125...

Multiples of 5: 100/5 = 20
Multiples of 25: 100/25 = 4
Multiples of 125: 100/125 = 0

Total zeros = 20 + 4 + 0 = 24

Explanation:
5, 10, 15... (20 numbers give one 5 each)
25, 50, 75, 100 (4 numbers give additional 5 each)

Answer: 24 trailing zeros
sections.formula:
Trailing zeros in n! = ⌊n/5⌋ + ⌊n/25⌋ + ⌊n/125⌋ + ...
Highest power of prime p in n! = ⌊n/p⌋ + ⌊n/p²⌋ + ⌊n/p³⌋ + ...
sections.shortcut:
• Usually only first 2-3 terms matter
• For 50!: 50/5=10, 50/25=2 → 12 zeros
• For 100!: Memorize 24 zeros
• For 1000!: 249 zeros

sections.name: Number of Factors
sections.theory:
If N = p^a × q^b × r^c (prime factorization)

Total factors = (a+1)(b+1)(c+1)
Sum of factors = [(p^(a+1)-1)/(p-1)] × [(q^(b+1)-1)/(q-1)] × ...
Product of factors = N^(Total factors/2)

Types of factors:
• Odd factors: Use only odd prime powers
• Even factors: Total - Odd
• Perfect square factors: Use only even powers
• Prime factors: Count distinct primes
sections.example:
Q: Find total factors and sum of factors of 36.

Solution:
Prime factorization: 36 = 2² × 3²

Total factors = (2+1)(2+1) = 3 × 3 = 9
Factors: 1, 2, 3, 4, 6, 9, 12, 18, 36

Sum of factors:
= [(2³-1)/(2-1)] × [(3³-1)/(3-1)]
= [(8-1)/1] × [(27-1)/2]
= 7 × 13
= 91

Verification: 1+2+3+4+6+9+12+18+36 = 91 ✓

Answer: 9 factors, Sum = 91
sections.formula:
Number of factors = (a+1)(b+1)(c+1) where N = p^a × q^b × r^c
Odd factors: If N = 2^a × m (m odd), odd factors = factors of m
Perfect square N: Factors are odd in count
Product of all factors = N^(d(N)/2) where d(N) = number of factors
sections.shortcut:
• Prime number has exactly 2 factors (1 and itself)
• Prime² has exactly 3 factors
• Prime³ has exactly 4 factors
• Perfect squares have ODD number of factors
• If N has k factors, product = N^(k/2)

sections.name: LCM and HCF Basics
sections.theory:
HCF (Highest Common Factor) / GCD (Greatest Common Divisor):
Largest number that divides all given numbers.

LCM (Least Common Multiple):
Smallest number that is divisible by all given numbers.

Key Relationship:
For two numbers a and b:
HCF(a,b) × LCM(a,b) = a × b

Methods to find:
1. Prime Factorization
2. Division Method
3. Euclidean Algorithm (for HCF)
sections.example:
Q: Find HCF and LCM of 12 and 18.

Solution (Prime Factorization):
12 = 2² × 3
18 = 2 × 3²

HCF: Take minimum powers
HCF = 2^min(2,1) × 3^min(1,2)
HCF = 2¹ × 3¹ = 2 × 3 = 6

LCM: Take maximum powers  
LCM = 2^max(2,1) × 3^max(1,2)
LCM = 2² × 3² = 4 × 9 = 36

Verification:
HCF × LCM = 6 × 36 = 216
a × b = 12 × 18 = 216 ✓

Answer: HCF = 6, LCM = 36
sections.formula:
HCF × LCM = Product of two numbers
HCF of fractions = HCF(numerators) / LCM(denominators)
LCM of fractions = LCM(numerators) / HCF(denominators)
HCF(a, b) = HCF(b, a mod b) [Euclidean Algorithm]
sections.shortcut:
• HCF ≤ min(a,b), LCM ≥ max(a,b)
• HCF divides LCM always
• For co-prime numbers: HCF = 1, LCM = a×b
• Consecutive numbers are always co-prime

sections.name: Remainder Theorem & Modular Arithmetic
sections.theory:
Dividend = Divisor × Quotient + Remainder
N = D × Q + R, where 0 ≤ R < D

Negative Remainder Concept:
Remainder can be -ve for easier calculation.
Example: 46 ÷ 5 = Remainder 1 OR Remainder -4

Modular Arithmetic:
a ≡ b (mod m) means a and b give same remainder when divided by m

Properties:
If a ≡ b (mod m), then:
• a + c ≡ b + c (mod m)
• a × c ≡ b × c (mod m)
• a^n ≡ b^n (mod m)
sections.example:
Q: Find remainder when 17^23 is divided by 5.

Solution (Using negative remainder):
17 ≡ -3 (mod 5)  [since 17 = 5×3 + 2 = 5×4 - 3]

17^23 ≡ (-3)^23 (mod 5)
     ≡ -(3^23) (mod 5)

Now 3^2 = 9 ≡ -1 (mod 5)

3^23 = 3^22 × 3
     = (3^2)^11 × 3
     ≡ (-1)^11 × 3 (mod 5)
     ≡ -1 × 3 (mod 5)
     ≡ -3 (mod 5)
     ≡ 2 (mod 5)

So 17^23 ≡ -2 ≡ 3 (mod 5)

Answer: Remainder is 3
sections.formula:
(a + b) mod n = [(a mod n) + (b mod n)] mod n
(a × b) mod n = [(a mod n) × (b mod n)] mod n
(a^m) mod n = [(a mod n)^m] mod n
Fermat's Little: If p is prime, a^(p-1) ≡ 1 (mod p)
Wilson's: (p-1)! ≡ -1 (mod p) for prime p
sections.shortcut:
• (x-1)^n / x → Remainder 1 if n even, x-1 if n odd
• (x+1)^n / x → Remainder 1 always
• For remainder by 9, use sum of digits
• For remainder by 11, use alternating sum

sections.name: HCF (Highest Common Factor)
sections.theory:
HCF (also called GCD - Greatest Common Divisor):
The largest number that divides all given numbers exactly.

Methods to find HCF:
1. Prime Factorization Method:
   - Find prime factors of each number
   - HCF = Product of common prime factors with lowest powers

2. Division Method (Euclidean Algorithm):
   - Divide larger by smaller
   - Replace larger with remainder
   - Repeat until remainder is 0
   - HCF = Last divisor

3. Listing Factors Method:
   - List all factors of each number
   - Find largest common factor
sections.example:
Q: Find HCF of 48 and 180 using all methods.

Method 1 (Prime Factorization):
48 = 2⁴ × 3¹
180 = 2² × 3² × 5¹

HCF = 2^min(4,2) × 3^min(1,2)
HCF = 2² × 3¹ = 4 × 3 = 12

Method 2 (Division Method):
180 = 48 × 3 + 36
48 = 36 × 1 + 12
36 = 12 × 3 + 0
HCF = 12 (last divisor)

Method 3 (Listing):
Factors of 48: 1,2,3,4,6,8,12,16,24,48
Factors of 180: 1,2,3,4,5,6,9,10,12,15,18,20,30,36,45,60,90,180
Common: 1,2,3,4,6,12
Highest = 12

Answer: HCF = 12
sections.formula:
For two numbers a, b:
HCF(a,b) × LCM(a,b) = a × b
HCF(a,b) = HCF(b, a mod b) [Euclidean]
HCF of three numbers: HCF(HCF(a,b), c)
HCF(ka, kb) = k × HCF(a,b)
sections.shortcut:
• HCF is always ≤ smallest number
• HCF of consecutive numbers = 1
• HCF of two prime numbers = 1
• HCF(a,b,c) divides (a+b+c)
• If one number divides another, smaller is HCF

sections.name: LCM (Least Common Multiple)
sections.theory:
LCM: The smallest number that is divisible by all given numbers.

Methods to find LCM:
1. Prime Factorization Method:
   - Find prime factors of each number
   - LCM = Product of all prime factors with highest powers

2. Division Method:
   - Divide numbers by common factors
   - Continue until no common factor remains
   - LCM = Product of all divisors × remaining numbers

3. Using HCF:
   - LCM = (a × b) / HCF(a,b)
sections.example:
Q: Find LCM of 12, 18, and 24.

Method 1 (Prime Factorization):
12 = 2² × 3¹
18 = 2¹ × 3²
24 = 2³ × 3¹

LCM = 2^max(2,1,3) × 3^max(1,2,1)
LCM = 2³ × 3² = 8 × 9 = 72

Method 2 (Division Method):
2 | 12  18  24
2 | 6   9   12
2 | 3   9   6
3 | 3   9   3
  | 1   3   1
3 | 1   3   1
  | 1   1   1

LCM = 2 × 2 × 2 × 3 × 3 = 72

Verification:
72 ÷ 12 = 6 ✓
72 ÷ 18 = 4 ✓
72 ÷ 24 = 3 ✓

Answer: LCM = 72
sections.formula:
For two numbers a, b:
LCM(a,b) = (a × b) / HCF(a,b)
LCM of three: LCM(LCM(a,b), c)
LCM(ka, kb) = k × LCM(a,b)
LCM × HCF = Product (for 2 numbers only)
sections.shortcut:
• LCM is always ≥ largest number
• LCM of co-prime numbers = their product
• If one divides another, larger is LCM
• LCM(a,b,c) is divisible by a, b, and c
• LCM of consecutive numbers ≈ their product

sections.name: HCF & LCM of Fractions
sections.theory:
For fractions:

HCF of fractions = HCF(numerators) / LCM(denominators)

LCM of fractions = LCM(numerators) / HCF(denominators)

Logic:
• HCF of fractions is the largest fraction dividing all
• LCM of fractions is the smallest fraction divisible by all
sections.example:
Q: Find HCF and LCM of 2/3, 4/9, and 8/27.

Solution:
Numerators: 2, 4, 8
Denominators: 3, 9, 27

HCF of numerators:
2 = 2¹
4 = 2²
8 = 2³
HCF = 2¹ = 2

LCM of numerators:
LCM = 2³ = 8

HCF of denominators:
3 = 3¹
9 = 3²
27 = 3³
HCF = 3¹ = 3

LCM of denominators:
LCM = 3³ = 27

HCF of fractions = 2/27
LCM of fractions = 8/3

Answer: HCF = 2/27, LCM = 8/3
sections.formula:
HCF(a/b, c/d) = HCF(numerators) / LCM(denominators)
LCM(a/b, c/d) = LCM(numerators) / HCF(denominators)
sections.shortcut:
• Simplify fractions first before calculation
• HCF of fractions is always ≤ smallest fraction
• LCM of fractions is always ≥ largest fraction

sections.name: LCM & HCF Word Problems - Type 1
sections.theory:
Bell/Light/Event Synchronization Problems:
• Events repeating at different intervals
• When do they occur together? → LCM
• How many times in given period?

Formula: Number of times = (Total Time / LCM) + 1
(+1 for the starting occurrence)
sections.example:
Q: Three bells toll at intervals of 9, 12, and 15 minutes. If they toll together at 8:00 AM, when will they toll together again? How many times will they toll together in 3 hours?

Solution:
Find LCM of 9, 12, 15

9 = 3²
12 = 2² × 3
15 = 3 × 5

LCM = 2² × 3² × 5 = 4 × 9 × 5 = 180 minutes

180 minutes = 3 hours

Next together: 8:00 AM + 3 hours = 11:00 AM

In 3 hours (180 min):
Number of times = (180/180) + 1 = 1 + 1 = 2 times
(At 8:00 AM and 11:00 AM)

Answer: 11:00 AM, 2 times total
sections.formula:
Meeting time = LCM(intervals)
Number of meetings = ⌊Total time / LCM⌋ + 1
Next meeting after nth = Start + n × LCM
sections.shortcut:
• For 2 events: LCM is usually small, manageable
• For prime intervals: LCM = product
• Don't forget to add 1 for starting time in count

sections.name: LCM & HCF Word Problems - Type 2
sections.theory:
Maximum Size/Capacity Problems:
• Dividing things into equal groups
• Largest tile/container that fits exactly → HCF
• Measuring/cutting to exact lengths

Logic: HCF gives the largest unit that divides all quantities exactly.
sections.example:
Q: Three ropes of lengths 624m, 936m, and 1040m need to be cut into equal pieces of maximum possible length. What is the length of each piece? How many pieces in total?

Solution:
Find HCF of 624, 936, 1040

624 = 2⁴ × 3 × 13
936 = 2³ × 3² × 13
1040 = 2⁴ × 5 × 13

HCF = 2³ × 13 = 8 × 13 = 104m

Length of each piece = 104m

Number of pieces:
624 ÷ 104 = 6
936 ÷ 104 = 9
1040 ÷ 104 = 10

Total pieces = 6 + 9 + 10 = 25

Answer: 104m per piece, 25 pieces total
sections.formula:
Maximum size = HCF(all quantities)
Number of pieces from each = Quantity / HCF
Total pieces = Sum of all individual pieces
sections.shortcut:
• Keywords: 'Maximum', 'Largest', 'Exactly' → HCF
• For square tile problems: HCF of length & width
• HCF result can be checked by division

sections.name: Number Problems with Remainders
sections.theory:
Number Problems with Remainders:

Type A: Number that leaves same remainder r when divided by a, b, c:
Answer = LCM(a,b,c) × k + r (where k = 0,1,2...)

Type B: Number that leaves remainders r₁, r₂, r₃ when divided by a, b, c where (a-r₁) = (b-r₂) = (c-r₃) = d:
Answer = LCM(a,b,c) - d

Type C: Largest number dividing x, y, z leaving remainders r₁, r₂, r₃:
Answer = HCF(x-r₁, y-r₂, z-r₃)
sections.example:
Q: Find the least number which when divided by 12, 15, and 18 leaves remainder 5 in each case.

Solution (Type A):
We need LCM(12,15,18) + 5

12 = 2² × 3
15 = 3 × 5
18 = 2 × 3²

LCM = 2² × 3² × 5 = 4 × 9 × 5 = 180

Least number = 180 + 5 = 185

Verification:
185 ÷ 12 = 15 remainder 5 ✓
185 ÷ 15 = 12 remainder 5 ✓
185 ÷ 18 = 10 remainder 5 ✓

Answer: 185
sections.formula:
Same remainder r: LCM + r
Different remainders (a-r₁=b-r₂=k): LCM - k
Divisor leaving remainders: HCF(differences)
Smallest divisible: LCM
sections.shortcut:
• 'Leaves remainder' → Add to LCM
• 'Exactly divisible' → Just LCM
• For largest divisor → Use HCF of differences
• If confusing, write out first few multiples

sections.name: LCM & HCF - Advanced Problems
sections.theory:
Traffic/Meeting on Circular Track:
• Two objects moving in SAME direction meet after: LCM(times)/|difference|
• Two objects moving in OPPOSITE direction meet after: LCM(times)/sum

Product of Numbers Given:
If HCF = h and LCM = l
Numbers can be h×a and h×b where:
• HCF(a,b) = 1 (co-prime)
• a×b = l/h

Ratio of Numbers Given:
If ratio a:b and HCF = h
Numbers are ah and bh where HCF(a,b) = 1
sections.example:
Q: Two numbers are in ratio 3:4. Their HCF is 5. Find the numbers and their LCM.

Solution:
Ratio = 3:4
HCF = 5

Numbers = 3×5 and 4×5 = 15 and 20

Verify HCF:
15 = 3 × 5
20 = 2² × 5
HCF = 5 ✓

Find LCM:
LCM = (15 × 20) / HCF
LCM = 300 / 5 = 60

Alternate:
15 = 3 × 5
20 = 2² × 5
LCM = 2² × 3 × 5 = 60 ✓

Answer: Numbers are 15 and 20, LCM = 60
sections.formula:
If ratio a:b and HCF = h:
Numbers = ah, bh
LCM = h × LCM(a,b) = h × ab (if co-prime)

If HCF and one number known:
Other = (HCF × LCM) / Known number
sections.shortcut:
• Ratio + HCF → Multiply ratio by HCF
• Product and HCF given → LCM = Product/HCF
• Sum and HCF/LCM → Try solving quadratic
• Always verify HCF condition after finding numbers

sections.name: Algebraic Identities - Basic
sections.theory:
Fundamental algebraic expansions for quick calculations:

1. (a + b)² = a² + 2ab + b²
2. (a - b)² = a² - 2ab + b²
3. (a + b)(a - b) = a² - b²
4. (a + b)² + (a - b)² = 2(a² + b²)
5. (a + b)² - (a - b)² = 4ab
6. a² + b² = (a + b)² - 2ab
7. a² + b² = (a - b)² + 2ab

These form the foundation for mental calculations and problem-solving.
sections.example:
Q: Calculate 103² - 97²

Solution (Using a² - b² = (a+b)(a-b)):
a = 103, b = 97

103² - 97² = (103 + 97)(103 - 97)
           = (200)(6)
           = 1200

Without identity:
103² = 10609
97² = 9409
Difference = 10609 - 9409 = 1200 ✓

Answer: 1200
sections.formula:
(a + b)² = a² + 2ab + b²
(a - b)² = a² - 2ab + b²
(a + b)(a - b) = a² - b²
(x + a)(x + b) = x² + (a+b)x + ab
sections.shortcut:
• For (a+b)²: Square both, add double product
• For a²-b²: Product of sum and difference
• 98² = (100-2)² = 10000 - 400 + 4 = 9604
• 52 × 48 = (50+2)(50-2) = 2500 - 4 = 2496

sections.name: Algebraic Identities - Cubic
sections.theory:
Cubic expansions:

1. (a + b)³ = a³ + 3a²b + 3ab² + b³ = a³ + b³ + 3ab(a + b)
2. (a - b)³ = a³ - 3a²b + 3ab² - b³ = a³ - b³ - 3ab(a - b)
3. a³ + b³ = (a + b)(a² - ab + b²)
4. a³ - b³ = (a - b)(a² + ab + b²)
5. a³ + b³ + c³ - 3abc = (a + b + c)(a² + b² + c² - ab - bc - ca)

Special case: If a + b + c = 0, then a³ + b³ + c³ = 3abc
sections.example:
Q: If x + 1/x = 5, find x³ + 1/x³

Solution:
Given: x + 1/x = 5

Cubing both sides:
(x + 1/x)³ = 5³
x³ + 1/x³ + 3(x)(1/x)(x + 1/x) = 125
x³ + 1/x³ + 3(1)(5) = 125
x³ + 1/x³ + 15 = 125
x³ + 1/x³ = 125 - 15 = 110

Alternate (Using formula):
(a + b)³ = a³ + b³ + 3ab(a + b)
a³ + b³ = (a + b)³ - 3ab(a + b)
x³ + 1/x³ = (5)³ - 3(1)(5) = 125 - 15 = 110

Answer: 110
sections.formula:
a³ + b³ = (a + b)³ - 3ab(a + b)
a³ - b³ = (a - b)³ + 3ab(a - b)
If a + b + c = 0: a³ + b³ + c³ = 3abc
sections.shortcut:
• x + 1/x = k → x² + 1/x² = k² - 2
• x + 1/x = k → x³ + 1/x³ = k³ - 3k
• x - 1/x = k → x² + 1/x² = k² + 2

sections.name: Quadratic Equations
sections.theory:
Standard form: ax² + bx + c = 0

Solutions (Roots):
x = [-b ± √(b² - 4ac)] / 2a

Discriminant D = b² - 4ac determines nature:
• D > 0: Two distinct real roots
• D = 0: Two equal real roots (repeated root)
• D < 0: No real roots (complex roots)

Sum and Product of Roots:
If α and β are roots:
α + β = -b/a
αβ = c/a

Equation from roots: x² - (sum)x + (product) = 0
sections.example:
Q: Find the values of k for which equation x² - (k+1)x + k² = 0 has equal roots.

Solution:
For equal roots: D = 0
b² - 4ac = 0

Here: a = 1, b = -(k+1), c = k²

D = [-(k+1)]² - 4(1)(k²) = 0
(k+1)² - 4k² = 0
k² + 2k + 1 - 4k² = 0
-3k² + 2k + 1 = 0
3k² - 2k - 1 = 0
3k² - 3k + k - 1 = 0
3k(k - 1) + 1(k - 1) = 0
(3k + 1)(k - 1) = 0

k = 1 or k = -1/3

Answer: k = 1 or k = -1/3
sections.formula:
Roots = [-b ± √(b²-4ac)] / 2a
Sum of roots α+β = -b/a
Product of roots αβ = c/a
|α - β| = √D / |a|
α² + β² = (α+β)² - 2αβ
sections.shortcut:
• If a+b+c = 0, roots are 1 and c/a
• If a-b+c = 0, roots are -1 and -c/a
• Both roots positive: sum>0, product>0
• Both roots negative: sum<0, product>0
• Opposite signs: product<0

sections.name: Arithmetic Progression (AP)
sections.theory:
Sequence where difference between consecutive terms is constant.

General form: a, a+d, a+2d, a+3d, ...
where a = first term, d = common difference

nth term: aₙ = a + (n-1)d

Sum of n terms:
Sₙ = n/2 [2a + (n-1)d]
OR Sₙ = n/2 [a + l]  where l = last term

Properties:
• aₙ - aₙ₋₁ = d (constant)
• Three terms in AP: a-d, a, a+d
• Four terms in AP: a-3d, a-d, a+d, a+3d
sections.example:
Q: The sum of first n terms of an AP is 3n² + 5n. Find the AP.

Solution:
Given: Sₙ = 3n² + 5n

For n = 1:
S₁ = a₁ = 3(1)² + 5(1) = 3 + 5 = 8
First term a = 8

For n = 2:
S₂ = 3(4) + 10 = 12 + 10 = 22
S₂ = a₁ + a₂
22 = 8 + a₂
a₂ = 14

Common difference d = a₂ - a₁ = 14 - 8 = 6

AP: 8, 14, 20, 26, ...

Verification:
a₃ = 8 + 2(6) = 20
S₃ = 3(9) + 15 = 42
a₁ + a₂ + a₃ = 8 + 14 + 20 = 42 ✓

Answer: AP is 8, 14, 20, 26, ...
sections.formula:
nth term: aₙ = a + (n-1)d
Sum: Sₙ = n/2[2a + (n-1)d]
Sum: Sₙ = n/2[first + last]
aₙ = Sₙ - Sₙ₋₁
Middle term (odd n): a(n+1)/2
sections.shortcut:
• Sum of first n natural: n(n+1)/2
• Sum of first n odd: n²
• Sum of first n even: n(n+1)
• AP with first=a, last=l, n terms: Sum = n(a+l)/2

sections.name: Geometric Progression (GP)
sections.theory:
Sequence where ratio between consecutive terms is constant.

General form: a, ar, ar², ar³, ...
where a = first term, r = common ratio

nth term: aₙ = arⁿ⁻¹

Sum of n terms:
• If r ≠ 1: Sₙ = a(rⁿ - 1)/(r - 1) OR a(1 - rⁿ)/(1 - r)
• If r = 1: Sₙ = na

Infinite GP (|r| < 1):
S∞ = a/(1 - r)

Properties:
• aₙ/aₙ₋₁ = r (constant)
• Three terms in GP: a/r, a, ar
• Four terms in GP: a/r³, a/r, ar, ar³
sections.example:
Q: Find the sum of series 1 + 1/2 + 1/4 + 1/8 + ... up to infinity.

Solution:
This is infinite GP with:
a = 1 (first term)
r = 1/2 (common ratio)

Since |r| = 1/2 < 1, sum exists.

S∞ = a/(1 - r)
   = 1/(1 - 1/2)
   = 1/(1/2)
   = 2

Verification (partial sums):
S₁ = 1
S₂ = 1.5
S₃ = 1.75
S₄ = 1.875
...
→ Approaching 2 ✓

Answer: 2
sections.formula:
nth term: aₙ = arⁿ⁻¹
Sum: Sₙ = a(rⁿ-1)/(r-1)
Infinite: S∞ = a/(1-r)  for |r|<1
Product of n terms: (a₁ × aₙ)ⁿ/²
GM = √(ab) for 2 terms
sections.shortcut:
• 1+2+4+8+... (n terms) = 2ⁿ - 1
• If 3 numbers in GP: middle² = product of extremes
• a, b, c in GP ⇒ b² = ac
• GP sum formula: Multiply by r, subtract

sections.name: Harmonic Progression & Means
sections.theory:
Harmonic Progression (HP):
Sequence where reciprocals form AP.
If a, b, c are in HP, then 1/a, 1/b, 1/c are in AP.

Means for two numbers a and b:

1. Arithmetic Mean (AM) = (a + b)/2
2. Geometric Mean (GM) = √(ab)
3. Harmonic Mean (HM) = 2ab/(a + b)

Relationship:
AM ≥ GM ≥ HM (Equality when a = b)
GM² = AM × HM
sections.example:
Q: Find HM of 4 and 12. Also verify AM ≥ GM ≥ HM.

Solution:
a = 4, b = 12

AM = (4 + 12)/2 = 16/2 = 8
GM = √(4 × 12) = √48 = 4√3 ≈ 6.93
HM = 2(4)(12)/(4 + 12) = 96/16 = 6

Verify inequality:
AM = 8
GM = 6.93
HM = 6

8 ≥ 6.93 ≥ 6 ✓

Verify GM² = AM × HM:
(6.93)² ≈ 48
8 × 6 = 48 ✓

Answer: HM = 6
sections.formula:
AM = (a+b)/2
GM = √(ab)
HM = 2ab/(a+b)
GM² = AM × HM
AM ≥ GM ≥ HM
sections.shortcut:
• For equal numbers: AM = GM = HM
• HM useful in speed problems (average speed)
• If a, b, c in HP: b = 2ac/(a+c)

sections.name: Logarithms
sections.theory:
If a^x = N, then x = log_a(N)
where a = base, N = number, x = logarithm

Basic Properties:
1. log_a(mn) = log_a(m) + log_a(n)
2. log_a(m/n) = log_a(m) - log_a(n)
3. log_a(m^n) = n × log_a(m)
4. log_a(1) = 0
5. log_a(a) = 1
6. a^(log_a(m)) = m
7. log_a(b) = 1/log_b(a)

Change of Base:
log_a(b) = log_c(b) / log_c(a)

Common Bases:
• log₁₀ = Common log (log)
• log_e = Natural log (ln)
• log₂ = Binary log
sections.formula:
log(ab) = log(a) + log(b)
log(a/b) = log(a) - log(b)
log(a^n) = n·log(a)
log_a(b) = log(b)/log(a)
log_a(b) × log_b(a) = 1
sections.shortcut:
• log(10) = 1, log(1) = 0
• log(2) ≈ 0.301, log(3) ≈ 0.477
• log(5) = log(10/2) = 1 - log(2) ≈ 0.699
• If log(x) = n.abc, then x has (n+1) digits

sections.name: Special Number Problems
sections.theory:
Finding values when relationships given:

Type 1: x + 1/x type problems
• Square to get x² + 1/x²
• Cube to get x³ + 1/x³

Type 2: Sum and Product given
If sum = S and product = P:
Numbers are roots of: t² - St + P = 0

Type 3: Ratio and Sum/Difference
If a:b = m:n and a+b = S:
a = mS/(m+n), b = nS/(m+n)
sections.example:
Q: Two numbers are in ratio 3:5 and their sum is 80. Find the numbers.

Solution:
Ratio = 3:5
Sum = 80

Let numbers be 3x and 5x
3x + 5x = 80
8x = 80
x = 10

Numbers are:
3x = 3(10) = 30
5x = 5(10) = 50

Verification:
Ratio: 30:50 = 3:5 ✓
Sum: 30 + 50 = 80 ✓

Alternate (Direct formula):
a = 3(80)/(3+5) = 240/8 = 30
b = 5(80)/(3+5) = 400/8 = 50

Answer: 30 and 50
sections.formula:
If x + 1/x = a:
x² + 1/x² = a² - 2
x³ + 1/x³ = a³ - 3a

If sum S, product P:
Numbers = [S ± √(S²-4P)]/2

Ratio m:n, sum S:
Numbers = mS/(m+n), nS/(m+n)
sections.shortcut:
• Ratio problems: Multiply by x, add, solve
• x² + 1/x² is always ≥ 2
• For sum-product: Use quadratic formula
• Verify answer by substitution

sections.name: Basic Average Concepts
sections.theory:
Average (Arithmetic Mean) = Sum of all values / Number of values

Key Properties:
1. If all values increase by x, average increases by x
2. If all values decrease by x, average decreases by x
3. If all values multiplied by x, average multiplied by x
4. If all values divided by x, average divided by x
5. Average lies between minimum and maximum values

Deviation Method:
Assumed Average method useful when numbers are large:
Actual Avg = Assumed Avg + (Sum of deviations / n)
sections.example:
Q: Find average of 23, 27, 31, 29, 25.

Method 1 (Direct):
Avg = (23+27+31+29+25)/5
    = 135/5
    = 27

Method 2 (Deviation from 25):
Deviations: -2, +2, +6, +4, 0
Sum of deviations = 10
Avg = 25 + 10/5 = 25 + 2 = 27 ✓

Answer: 27
sections.formula:
Average = Sum / n
Sum = Average × n
n = Sum / Average
New Avg = Old Avg + Change (if all increase by same)
Deviation Avg = Assumed + (Σ deviations / n)
sections.shortcut:
• For consecutive numbers: Avg = (First + Last)/2
• For AP: Avg = Middle term
• If numbers symmetric around x: Avg = x
• First n naturals: Avg = (n+1)/2

sections.name: Weighted Average
sections.theory:
When different values have different weights/frequencies.

Weighted Average = (w₁x₁ + w₂x₂ + ... + wₙxₙ) / (w₁ + w₂ + ... + wₙ)

where w = weight, x = value

Common in:
• Combining groups with different sizes
• Marks with different weightages
• Prices with different quantities
sections.example:
Q: A class has 30 students with average weight 40kg. Another class has 20 students with average 50kg. Find combined average weight.

Solution:
Group 1: n₁ = 30, avg₁ = 40kg
Group 2: n₂ = 20, avg₂ = 50kg

Total weight = 30(40) + 20(50)
             = 1200 + 1000
             = 2200 kg

Total students = 30 + 20 = 50

Combined average = 2200/50 = 44 kg

Alternate (Weighted formula):
Avg = (30×40 + 20×50)/(30+20)
    = 2200/50 = 44 kg

Answer: 44 kg
sections.formula:
Weighted Avg = Σ(weight × value) / Σweight
Combined Avg = (n₁A₁ + n₂A₂ + ...)/(n₁+n₂+...)
For 2 groups: (n₁A₁ + n₂A₂)/(n₁+n₂)
sections.shortcut:
• Weighted avg closer to group with larger weight
• Use Alligation for 2 groups ratio method
• Check: Result must be between individual averages

sections.name: Alligation Method
sections.theory:
Quick method for mixing two quantities to find ratio.

Used when:
• Two groups with different averages combine
• Need to find ratio of quantities

Formula (Visual):
      Cheaper(C)    Dearer(D)
           \        /
            Mean(M)
           /        \
       (D-M)      (M-C)

Ratio = (D-M):(M-C)

Reversed cross-subtraction gives ratio.
sections.example:
Q: Students with avg 40kg and 50kg are mixed to get avg 44kg. Find ratio.

Solution using Alligation:
Lower avg (C) = 40
Higher avg (D) = 50  
Mean (M) = 44

       40        50
         \      /
           44
         /    \
      (50-44) (44-40)
         6       4

Ratio = 6:4 = 3:2

Meaning: 3 parts of 40kg group, 2 parts of 50kg group

Verification:
If 30 students (40kg) and 20 students (50kg):
(30×40 + 20×50)/50 = 2200/50 = 44 ✓

Answer: 3:2
sections.formula:
Ratio of quantities = (Higher - Mean):(Mean - Lower)
n₁:n₂ = (A₂ - A_combined):(A_combined - A₁)
sections.shortcut:
• Alligation is faster than weighted avg for ratios
• Cross-subtract: Higher-Mean and Mean-Lower
• Simplify ratio at end
• Mean must be between two averages

sections.name: Replacement Problems - Type 1
sections.theory:
When one person/item leaves and another joins:

New Average = Old Average + [(New - Old) / Total count]

OR

New person's value = Old Avg × Count + Increase × Count

Commonly asked:
• Student replaced, average changes
• Player replaced, average changes
sections.example:
Q: Average age of 11 players is 28 years. If captain (age 32) is replaced by new player, average becomes 27. Find new player's age.

Solution:
Old avg = 28, n = 11
New avg = 27

Decrease in avg = 28 - 27 = 1 year

Total decrease = 1 × 11 = 11 years

New player's age = Captain's age - Total decrease
                 = 32 - 11
                 = 21 years

Alternate method:
Old sum = 28 × 11 = 308
New sum = 27 × 11 = 297
Difference = 308 - 297 = 11
New player = 32 - 11 = 21

Answer: 21 years
sections.formula:
Replaced value = Removed value + (Avg change × n)
New item = Old Avg + (Avg decrease × Total) - Old item
If avg increases: New > Old
If avg decreases: New < Old
sections.shortcut:
• Change in total = Change in avg × Count
• New = Old + Net change
• If avg goes up, new item is heavier/larger

sections.name: Replacement Problems - Type 2
sections.theory:
When person/item added (count increases):

New person's value = Old Avg + (Avg increase × New total count)

When person/item removed (count decreases):

Removed value = Old Avg - (Avg increase × New count)

Common scenarios:
• Teacher joins class
• New member in team
sections.example:
Q: Average weight of 24 students is 35kg. When teacher joins, average becomes 36kg. Find teacher's weight.

Solution:
Old: n = 24, avg = 35kg
New: n = 25, avg = 36kg

Method 1:
Old sum = 24 × 35 = 840 kg
New sum = 25 × 36 = 900 kg
Teacher's weight = 900 - 840 = 60 kg

Method 2 (Shortcut):
Increase in avg = 1 kg
This 1kg increase for all 24 students = 24kg
Plus the teacher's own contribution above new avg
Teacher = New avg + (Increase × Old count)
        = 36 + (1 × 24)
        = 36 + 24 = 60 kg

Answer: 60 kg
sections.formula:
Added person = New Avg + (Avg increase × Old count)
Removed person = Old Avg - (Avg decrease × New count)
Change in sum = Added/Removed value
sections.shortcut:
• Teacher problem: Almost always addition
• Formula: New avg + (increase × old n)
• Verify: New value should raise average

sections.name: Average Speed
sections.theory:
Average speed ≠ Average of speeds (usually)

For different distances/times:
Avg Speed = Total Distance / Total Time

Special Cases:

1. Equal distances at speeds u and v:
   Avg Speed = 2uv/(u+v)  [Harmonic Mean]

2. Equal times at speeds u and v:
   Avg Speed = (u+v)/2  [Arithmetic Mean]

3. Three equal distances u, v, w:
   Avg = 3uvw/(uv+vw+uw)
sections.example:
Q: A person travels 60km at 30 km/hr and returns 60km at 60 km/hr. Find average speed.

Solution:
Distance 1 = 60 km, Speed 1 = 30 km/hr
Time 1 = 60/30 = 2 hours

Distance 2 = 60 km, Speed 2 = 60 km/hr  
Time 2 = 60/60 = 1 hour

Total distance = 120 km
Total time = 3 hours

Avg speed = 120/3 = 40 km/hr

Using formula (Equal distances):
Avg = 2(30)(60)/(30+60)
    = 3600/90
    = 40 km/hr ✓

Note: (30+60)/2 = 45 ≠ 40

Answer: 40 km/hr
sections.formula:
Avg Speed = Total Dist / Total Time
Equal distances: 2uv/(u+v)
Equal times: (u+v)/2
3 equal distances: 3uvw/(uv+vw+uw)
sections.shortcut:
• Never just average the speeds
• Equal distance → Use Harmonic Mean
• Equal time → Use Arithmetic Mean
• Round trip → Usually equal distances

sections.name: Cricket Batting Average
sections.theory:
Batting Average = Total Runs / Number of times out

Note: NOT divided by innings played, but times OUT

Common problems:
• Average after n innings
• Runs needed for target average
• Average increase after scoring x runs
sections.example:
Q: Batsman has average 42 after 10 innings. How many runs in 11th to make average 45?

Solution:
Current: 10 innings, avg 42
Total runs so far = 10 × 42 = 420

Required: 11 innings, avg 45
Required total = 11 × 45 = 495

Runs needed in 11th = 495 - 420 = 75

Alternate (Shortcut):
Increase needed = 45 - 42 = 3
For 10 past innings to increase by 3 each = 30
Plus reach 45 in current = 45
Total = 30 + 45 = 75 ✓

Answer: 75 runs
sections.formula:
New runs = (Target avg × New total) - Current total
New runs = New avg + (Increase × Old innings)
sections.shortcut:
• Increase × old innings gives base
• Add new average to get total
• Total runs ≠ avg × innings if not always out

sections.name: Ages Average Problems
sections.theory:
Age averages similar to regular averages.

Key points:
• After n years, everyone's age increases by n
• After n years, average increases by n
• Age difference remains constant
• Birth adds person, death removes person
sections.example:
Q: Average age of family of 6 is 25 years. If age of youngest (5 years) excluded, average becomes 27. Find age of youngest when born.

Solution:
With youngest: n=6, avg=25
Total age = 6 × 25 = 150 years

Without youngest: n=5, avg=27  
Total of 5 = 5 × 27 = 135 years

Youngest's age = 150 - 135 = 15 years

Wait, problem says youngest is 5 years.
This means:
When youngest born, others had total = 135 years
Now (5 yrs later), others have 135 + 5×5 = 160
Total now = 160 + 5 = 165

Actually, let me recalculate:
Current total with youngest = 150
Youngest is 5
Others total = 145

When youngest born (5 years ago):
Others were 145 - 25 = 120 years
Youngest was 0
Total then = 120
Average then = 120/6 = 20 years

Answer: Average was 20 years when youngest born
sections.formula:
After n years: New avg = Old avg + n
Before n years: Old avg = Current avg - n
sections.shortcut:
• Everyone ages equally
• Average ages at same rate
• Birth/death changes count

sections.name: Fraction - Percentage Conversions
sections.formula:
x% of y = (x/100) × y
Percentage change = [ (Final - Initial) / Initial ] × 100
sections.shortcut:
• A% of B = B% of A
• To increase by x%, multiply by (1 + x/100)
• To decrease by x%, multiply by (1 - x/100)

sections.name: Successive Percentage Changes
sections.theory:
When a value is modified multiple times in sequence.

Net Percentage Change for two successive changes x% and y%:
Net % = x + y + (xy/100)

Note: Use +ve for increase and -ve for decrease.
sections.example:
Q: A price increases by 20% and then decreases by 10%. Find net change.

Solution:
x = 20, y = -10
Net % = 20 + (-10) + (20 × -10)/100
Net % = 10 - 2 = 8%

Since positive, it is an 8% increase.

Answer: 8% Increase
sections.formula:
Net % = x + y + (xy/100)
For three changes: Use formula on first two, then on result and third.
sections.shortcut:
• If value increases and then decreases by same x%, always a loss of (x/10)² %
• Use Multiplying Factors: 1.2 × 0.9 = 1.08 (8% increase)

sections.name: Product Constancy (Price & Consumption)
sections.theory:
Expenditure = Price × Consumption
If Expenditure is constant, and Price increases by x%, Consumption must decrease to compensate.

If Price increases by (1/n), Consumption decreases by 1/(n+1).
If Price decreases by (1/n), Consumption increases by 1/(n-1).
sections.example:
Q: Price of sugar increases by 25%. By what % should a family reduce consumption to keep expenditure same?

Solution:
Method 1 (Fraction):
25% = 1/4 (Increase)
Consumption must decrease by 1/(4+1) = 1/5
1/5 = 20%

Method 2 (Formula):
[x / (100 + x)] × 100
= [25 / 125] × 100 = 20%

Answer: 20%
sections.formula:
Reduction % = [x / (100 + x)] × 100
Increase % = [x / (100 - x)] × 100

sections.name: Election & Voting Problems
sections.theory:
Total Votes = Votes Polled + Did Not Vote
Votes Polled = Valid Votes + Invalid Votes
Winner's Margin = Winner's Votes - Runner-up's Votes
sections.example:
Q: In an election, winner got 60% of total valid votes and won by 12,000 votes. Find total valid votes if there were only two candidates.

Solution:
Winner = 60%
Runner-up = 40%
Margin = 60% - 40% = 20%
20% of Total = 12,000
(1/5) × Total = 12,000
Total = 60,000

Answer: 60,000
sections.formula:
Margin = (Winner % - Loser %) × Total Valid Votes
Valid = Total × (1 - Invalid %)
sections.shortcut:
• Start with 100x for total votes
• Deduct 'Did not vote' and 'Invalid' step by step

sections.name: Population & Depreciation
sections.theory:
Similar to Compound Interest.
Population after n years = P × (1 + R/100)ⁿ
Value after n years (Depreciation) = V × (1 - R/100)ⁿ
sections.example:
Q: The value of a machine depreciates by 10% every year. If current value is 10,000, find value after 2 years.

Solution:
V = 10,000, R = 10%, n = 2
V₂ = 10,000 × (1 - 0.1)²
V₂ = 10,000 × (0.9)²
V₂ = 10,000 × 0.81 = 8,100

Answer: 8,100
sections.formula:
Future Value = P(1 ± R/100)ⁿ
Initial Value = P / (1 ± R/100)ⁿ
sections.shortcut:
• Use successive change logic (multiplying factors)
• r = 10% for 2 years (net decrease) = -10 -10 + 1 = -19%

sections.name: Exam & Venn Diagram Problems
sections.theory:
Problems involving percentage of students passing/failing in subjects.

Formula: n(A ∪ B) = n(A) + n(B) - n(A ∩ B)
In %: Total % = %A + %B - %Both + %None
sections.example:
Q: In an exam, 40% failed in Math, 30% failed in English and 15% failed in both. Find % of students passed in both.

Solution:
Fail in A (Math) = 40%
Fail in B (English) = 30%
Fail in Both = 15%
Total Failed = 40 + 30 - 15 = 55%
Passed in Both = 100% - Total Failed = 100 - 55 = 45%

Answer: 45%
sections.formula:
% Total = %A + %B - %Both + %None
Passed in Both = 100 - (Fail A + Fail B - Fail Both)
sections.shortcut:
• Draw a quick Venn diagram
• Fill 'Both' first, then subtract from individual counts

sections.name: Basic Terms & Concepts
sections.theory:
Profit and Loss are calculated by comparing the Cost Price (CP) and Selling Price (SP).

• Cost Price (CP): Price at which an article is purchased.
• Selling Price (SP): Price at which an article is sold.
• Profit (Gain): If SP > CP, then Profit = SP - CP.
• Loss: If CP > SP, then Loss = CP - SP.

Profit or Loss is ALWAYS calculated on CP unless specified otherwise.
sections.example:
Q: An article is bought for ₹800 and sold for ₹960. Find the profit percentage.

Solution:
CP = ₹800, SP = ₹960
Profit = SP - CP = 960 - 800 = ₹160
Profit % = (Profit / CP) × 100
Profit % = (160 / 800) × 100
Profit % = 1/5 × 100 = 20%

Answer: 20%
sections.formula:
Profit % = (Profit / CP) × 100
Loss % = (Loss / CP) × 100
SP = [ (100 + P%) / 100 ] × CP
CP = [ 100 / (100 + P%) ] × SP
sections.shortcut:
• Use multiplying factors for speed: 20% profit means SP = 1.2 × CP
• 10% loss means SP = 0.9 × CP

sections.name: Markup & Discount
sections.theory:
Markup is the amount added to CP to reach the Marked Price (MP). Discount is the reduction given on MP to reach the SP.

• Marked Price (MP): List price or tag price.
• Markup = MP - CP
• Discount = MP - SP

Markup % is calculated on CP. Discount % is calculated on MP.
sections.example:
Q: A shopkeeper marks up his goods by 40% and then gives a discount of 20%. Find his net profit percentage.

Solution:
Let CP = 100
Markup 40% → MP = 140
Discount 20% on MP → SP = 140 - (20% of 140) = 140 - 28 = 112
Profit = SP - CP = 112 - 100 = 12
Profit % = 12%

Alternative (Successive Change Formula):
Net % = x + y + xy/100
Net % = 40 - 20 - (40 × 20)/100 = 20 - 8 = 12%

Answer: 12%
sections.formula:
Discount % = (Discount / MP) × 100
Markup % = (MP - CP)/CP × 100
MP / CP = (100 + P%) / (100 - D%)
sections.shortcut:
• MP/CP ratio = (100 + Success%) / (100 - Discount%)
• Buy 4 get 1 Free: Discount = 1/(4+1) = 20%

sections.name: Dishonest Dealer Problems
sections.theory: Cases where a dealer cheats in weight or price. The profit depends on the actual weight given vs the weight for which money is taken.
sections.example:
Q: A dishwasher dealer claims to sell at CP but uses a weight of 900g instead of 1kg. Find his profit percentage.

Solution:
Actual weight given = 900g
Weight charged for = 1000g
Profit = 1000 - 900 = 100g
Dealer makes 100g profit on every 900g he gives.
Profit % = (Error / Actual weight given) × 100
Profit % = (100 / 900) × 100 = 11.11%

Answer: 11.11%
sections.formula:
Profit % = [ (True Weight - False Weight) / False Weight ] × 100
Net Gain Factor = (Price Gain Factor) × (Weight Gain Factor)
sections.shortcut: • Think: He gives 900g but takes money for 1000g. Profit is 100g on 900g given.

sections.name: Special Profit/Loss Cases
sections.theory:
Case 1: Same CP of two items, one sold at x% profit and another at x% loss → No Profit No Loss.
Case 2: Same SP of two items, one sold at x% profit and another at x% loss → Always a LOSS of (x/10)² %.
sections.example:
Q: Two watches are sold for ₹1200 each. One is sold at 20% profit and the other at 20% loss. Find the net profit or loss percentage.

Solution:
SP of both is same.
Loss % = (x/10)² = (20/10)² = 2² = 4%

Answer: 4% Loss
sections.formula:
Loss % = (Common % / 10)²
Overall SP / CP relation: Successive percentage logic
sections.shortcut:
• For Type 2, the owner always loses.
• If SP is same, net loss % does not depend on the ₹ amount.

sections.name: Profit & Loss in Ratios
sections.theory: Sometimes profit/loss is given in terms of number of articles.
sections.example:
Q: CP of 15 articles is equal to SP of 12 articles. Find the profit percentage.

Solution:
15 CP = 12 SP
CP / SP = 12 / 15 = 4 / 5
Let CP = 4, SP = 5
Profit = 1
Profit % = (1 / 4) × 100 = 25%

Answer: 25%
sections.formula: Profit % = [ (Articles Bought - Articles Sold) / Articles Sold ] × 100
sections.shortcut:
• If CP of x = SP of y:
Profit/Loss % = (x-y)/y × 100
Positive = Profit, Negative = Loss

sections.name: Simple Interest (SI) Basics
sections.theory:
Simple Interest is the interest calculated fixedly on the original principal for the entire period.

• Principal (P): The money borrowed or lent.
• Rate (R): The interest rate per annum (p.a.).
• Time (T): The duration for which the money is kept.
• Amount (A): Total money returned (Principal + Interest).
sections.example:
Q: Find the simple interest on ₹5,000 at 10% per annum for 3 years.

Solution:
P = ₹5,000, R = 10%, T = 3 years
SI = (P × R × T) / 100
SI = (5,000 × 10 × 3) / 100
SI = 50 × 10 × 3 = ₹1,500
Total Amount = 5,000 + 1,500 = ₹6,500

Answer: ₹1,500
sections.shortcut:
• If a sum doubles itself in T years, R = 100/T
• If a sum becomes n times itself in T years, R = [100(n-1)] / T

sections.name: Compound Interest (CI) Basics
sections.theory:
In Compound Interest, the interest earned in one period is added to the principal to calculate the interest for the next period (Interest on Interest).

• Compounding: Adding interest to the principal at regular intervals.
• Annual Compounding: Interest added once a year.
sections.example:
Q: Find the compound interest on ₹8,000 at 5% per annum for 2 years, compounded annually.

Solution:
P = ₹8,000, R = 5%, n = 2
A = P [ 1 + R/100 ]ⁿ
A = 8,000 [ 1 + 5/100 ]²
A = 8,000 [ 21/20 ]² = 8,000 × 441/400
A = 20 × 441 = ₹8,820
CI = A - P = 8,820 - 8,000 = ₹820

Answer: ₹820
sections.shortcut:
• Successive Percentage Change logic: For 2 years at r%, net r% = 2r + r²/100
• For 5% (2 years), net CI % = 5+5 + (25/100) = 10.25%

sections.name: Different Compounding Periods
sections.theory:
Interest can be compounded more than once a year. When frequency changes, the Rate and Time must be adjusted accordingly.

• Half-yearly: Rate becomes R/2, Time becomes 2n
• Quarterly: Rate becomes R/4, Time becomes 4n
sections.example:
Q: Find CI on ₹10,000 for 1 year at 20% p.a. compounded half-yearly.

Solution:
P = 10,000, R = 20% p.a. → 10% per half-year
Time = 1 year → 2 half-years
A = 10,000 [ 1 + 10/100 ]²
A = 10,000 × 1.21 = ₹12,100
CI = 12,100 - 10,000 = ₹2,100

Answer: ₹2,100
sections.formula: A = P [ 1 + (R/k)/100 ]^(nk) where k is frequency per year.
sections.shortcut: • Compounded half-yearly gives more interest than annually for same rate/time.

sections.name: Difference between CI and SI
sections.theory: This is a very common interview question. For the first year, CI and SI are the same (if compounded annually). From the second year, the difference starts.
sections.example:
Q: Find the difference between CI and SI on ₹4,000 at 10% p.a. for 2 years.

Solution:
Method 1 (Direct Formula):
Diff = P (R/100)²
Diff = 4,000 × (10/100)² = 4,000 × 1/100 = ₹40

Method 2 (Logic):
SI for 1st yr = 400. SI for 2nd yr = 400. Total SI = 800.
CI for 1st yr = 400. 2nd yr Principal = 4400.
Interest for 2nd yr = 4400 × 10% = 440.
Total CI = 400 + 440 = 840.
Diff = 840 - 800 = ₹40.

Answer: ₹40
sections.formula:
Difference for 2 years = P (R/100)²
Difference for 3 years = P (R/100)² [ 3 + R/100 ]
sections.shortcut: • For 2 years, the difference is simply the interest on the first year's interest.

sections.name: CI & SI Installments
sections.theory: Paying back a loan in equal periodic payments.
sections.example:
Q: A sum of ₹2,100 is borrowed at 10% CI to be paid back in 2 equal annual installments. Find the value of each installment.

Solution:
Let installment be x.
Principal = PV of 1st + PV of 2nd
2100 = x/(1+10/100) + x/(1+10/100)²
2100 = x/(1.1) + x/(1.21)
2100 = (1.1x + x) / 1.21
2100 = 2.1x / 1.21
x = (2100 × 1.21) / 2.1 = 1000 × 1.21 = ₹1,210

Answer: ₹1,210
sections.formula:
For CI: P = x/(1+r) + x/(1+r)² + ...
For SI: Installment x = [ 100P ] / [ 100T + RT(T-1)/2 ]
sections.shortcut: • For CI 2 installments at 10%, ratio of P to x is 210:121. Scale according to P.

sections.name: Ratio & Proportion Basics
sections.theory:
A Ratio is a comparison of two quantities of the same kind by division. Proportion is an equality of two ratios.

• Duplicate Ratio of a:b is a²:b²
• Sub-duplicate Ratio of a:b is √a:√b
• Mean Proportional between a and b is √(ab)
• Third Proportional to a and b is b²/a
• Fourth Proportional to a, b, c is (b×c)/a
sections.example:
Q: Find the fourth proportional to 4, 9, 12.

Solution:
Let fourth proportional be x.
4/9 = 12/x
4x = 9 × 12
4x = 108
x = 27

Answer: 27
sections.formula:
If a/b = c/d, then ad = bc
Mean proportional = √(ab)
Direct Proportion: y = kx
Inverse Proportion: y = k/x
sections.shortcut: • Compounded Ratio: If a:b and c:d are given, compounded is ac:bd

sections.name: Comparing & Dividing Ratios
sections.theory: To compare ratios, convert them to fractions with the same denominator. To divide a quantity in a ratio a:b, the parts are [a/(a+b)] × Total and [b/(a+b)] × Total.
sections.example:
Q: Divide ₹1,200 between A and B in ratio 3:5.

Solution:
Total parts = 3 + 5 = 8
A's share = (3/8) × 1,200 = 3 × 150 = ₹450
B's share = (5/8) × 1,200 = 5 × 150 = ₹750

Answer: A = ₹450, B = ₹750
sections.formula: Share of x = [ ratio_x / sum_of_ratios ] × total_quantity
sections.shortcut: • Scaling Ratios: If a:b = 2:3 and b:c = 4:5, find a:b:c by making 'b' same (8:12:15).

sections.name: Coin & Bag Problems
sections.theory: Problems where a bag contains different denominations of coins in a given ratio. There are two variables: the Number of coins and the Value of coins.
sections.example:
Q: A bag contains 50p, 25p, and 10p coins in ratio 5:9:4, amounting to ₹206. Find the number of coins of each type.

Solution:
Ratio of numbers = 5x : 9x : 4x
Value conversion (in ₹):
50p = 0.5, 25p = 0.25, 10p = 0.1
Total Value = 5x(0.5) + 9x(0.25) + 4x(0.1) = 206
2.5x + 2.25x + 0.4x = 206
5.15x = 206
x = 206 / 5.15 = 40

Numbers:
50p = 5 × 40 = 200
25p = 9 × 40 = 360
10p = 4 × 40 = 160

Answer: (200, 360, 160)
sections.formula: Total Value = Σ (Number of coins × Face Value)
sections.shortcut: • Work with smallest units (paise) to avoid decimals: 50(5x) + 25(9x) + 10(4x) = 20600

sections.name: Partnership Basics
sections.theory:
Partnership is an association of two or more persons to carry out a business. Profits are distributed based on the investment and the time period.

Profit Ratio = (Capital_A × Time_A) : (Capital_B × Time_B)
sections.example:
Q: A and B invest ₹20,000 and ₹30,000 for 1 year and 2 years respectively. Find their profit share ratio.

Solution:
Capital A = 20,000, Time A = 1 yr
Capital B = 30,000, Time B = 2 yr
Profit A : Profit B = (20,000 × 1) : (30,000 × 2)
Ratio = 20,000 : 60,000 = 1 : 3

Answer: 1:3
sections.formula:
P1/P2 = (C1 × T1) / (C2 × T2)
Active partner usually gets extra commission.
sections.shortcut:
• If time is same, Profit Ratio = Capital Ratio.
• If capital is same, Profit Ratio = Time Ratio.

sections.name: Problems on Ages (Ratio focus)
sections.theory: Age problems involving ratio changes over time. Remember: the age difference between two people always remains constant.
sections.example:
Q: Ratio of ages of A and B is 4:5. After 5 years, the ratio becomes 5:6. Find their present ages.

Solution:
Present: 4x, 5x
After 5 yrs: (4x + 5)/(5x + 5) = 5/6
24x + 30 = 25x + 25
x = 5
Present ages = 4(5) and 5(5) = 20 and 25 years.

Answer: 20 and 25 years
sections.formula:
x years from now = Current + x
x years ago = Current - x
sections.shortcut: • Look at the parts difference: 4:5 to 5:6 (both differ by 1 part). This 1 part = 5 years. So 4 parts = 20, 5 parts = 25.

sections.name: Rule of Alligation
sections.theory:
Alligation is a rule that enables us to find the ratio in which two or more ingredients at their respective prices must be mixed to produce a mixture of a specified price.

• Cheaper quantity (c): The ingredient with the lower price.
• Dearer quantity (d): The ingredient with the higher price.
• Mean Price (m): The cost price of a unit of the mixture.
sections.example:
Q: In what ratio must rice at ₹20 per kg be mixed with rice at ₹30 per kg so that the mixture is worth ₹24 per kg?

Solution:
Cheaper (c) = 20, Dearer (d) = 30, Mean (m) = 24
Ratio = (d - m) : (m - c)
Ratio = (30 - 24) : (24 - 20)
Ratio = 6 : 4 = 3 : 2

Answer: 3:2
sections.formula: Quantity of Cheaper / Quantity of Dearer = (CP of Dearer - Mean Price) / (Mean Price - CP of Cheaper)
sections.shortcut: • Alligation works on weighted averages. Use it for speeds, interests, and profit percentages too.

sections.name: Mean Price calculation
sections.theory: If the ratio of ingredients and their individual prices are given, we can find the mean price of the mixture using the weighted average method.
sections.example:
Q: 5kg of variety A tea at ₹40/kg is mixed with 3kg of variety B tea at ₹60/kg. Find the cost of the mixture per kg.

Solution:
Total Cost = (5 × 40) + (3 × 60) = 200 + 180 = 380
Total Weight = 5 + 3 = 8kg
Mean Price = 380 / 8 = ₹47.50

Answer: ₹47.50 per kg
sections.formula: Mean Price = (q1c1 + q2c2) / (q1 + q2)
sections.shortcut: • Use the deviation method from a base price for quick mental calculation.

sections.name: Replacement Formula (Liquids)
sections.theory: This involves a container filled with a pure liquid (e.g., wine), and a part of it is replaced x amount of times by another liquid (e.g., water).
sections.example:
Q: A container contains 40 liters of milk. From this container, 4 liters of milk was taken out and replaced by water. This process was repeated further two times. How much milk is now contained by the container?

Solution:
Initial Capacity (C) = 40, Quantity replaced (x) = 4, Number of operations (n) = 3 (Initial + 2 more)
Milk Left = 40 [ 1 - 4/40 ]³
Milk Left = 40 [ 9/10 ]³ = 40 × 729/1000
Milk Left = 4 × 0.729 × 10 = 29.16 liters

Answer: 29.16 liters
sections.formula: Final Quantity = Initial Quantity [ 1 - x/C ]ⁿ where x is replaced volume, C is capacity, n is operations.
sections.shortcut: • For 10% replacement (4/40), use 0.9 as multiplying factor: 40 × 0.9 × 0.9 × 0.9.

sections.name: Mixing Two Mixtures
sections.theory: When two already mixed solutions (e.g., Milk:Water) are mixed together to form a third mixture.
sections.example:
Q: Container A has milk and water in ratio 5:2. Container B has them in 8:5. In what ratio should these be mixed to get a mixture with milk and water in ratio 9:4?

Solution:
Look at the fraction of milk:
A = 5/7, B = 8/13, Target = 9/13
Using Alligation on milk fraction:
       5/7        8/13
            9/13
    (9/13 - 8/13)  (5/7 - 9/13)
        1/13 : (65-63)/91
        1/13 : 2/91
        (1/13 × 91) : 2 = 7 : 2

Answer: 7:2
sections.formula: Apply alligation rule on a single component's concentration (e.g., just milk fraction).
sections.shortcut: • Always choose the quantity that is easier to calculate (smaller numbers).

sections.name: Alligation in P&L and Interest
sections.theory: Alligation can be used to solve problems where total profit/interest is given for two parts of an investment.
sections.example:
Q: A man lent ₹2000, part at 5% and rest at 4% per annum. Total interest after 1 year was ₹92. Find the sum lent at 5%.

Solution:
Overall Interest % = (92 / 2000) × 100 = 4.6%
Using Alligation on Rates:
       5%        4%
           4.6%
     (4.6-4) : (5-4.6)
       0.6 : 0.4 = 3 : 2
Sum at 5% = (3/5) × 2000 = ₹1200

Answer: ₹1200
sections.formula: Rate1 : Rate2 :: (Mean Rate - Rate2) : (Rate1 - Mean Rate)
sections.shortcut: • Total interest/profit percentage must always lie between the two individual rates/percentages.

sections.name: Basic Time & Work (LCM Method)
sections.theory:
Time and Work share an inverse relationship. If a person completes a work in 'n' days, then in 1 day he does 1/n part of the work.

LCM Method: Assume total work as the LCM of all given time periods. This avoids working with fractions.
sections.example:
Q: A can do a work in 10 days and B in 15 days. In how many days can they complete it together?

Solution:
LCM of 10 and 15 is 30. Let Total Work = 30 units.
A's efficiency (work/day) = 30 / 10 = 3 units/day
B's efficiency (work/day) = 30 / 15 = 2 units/day
Combined efficiency = 3 + 2 = 5 units/day
Time taken together = Total work / Total efficiency = 30 / 5 = 6 days.

Answer: 6 days
sections.formula:
1/Total Time = 1/T1 + 1/T2 + ...
Work = Efficiency × Time
sections.shortcut: • For two people: Time = (A × B) / (A + B)

sections.name: Efficiency & Ratios
sections.theory: Efficiency (E) is inversely proportional to Time (T). If A is twice as efficient as B, A will take half the time to complete the same work.
sections.example:
Q: A is thrice as efficient as B and therefore takes 60 days less than B to finish a job. Find the time in which they can do it together.

Solution:
Efficiency Ratio A:B = 3:1
Time Ratio A:B = 1:3
Difference in time parts = 3 - 1 = 2 parts
2 parts = 60 days
1 part (A's time) = 30 days
3 parts (B's time) = 90 days
Together = (30 × 90) / (30 + 90) = 2700 / 120 = 22.5 days

Answer: 22.5 days
sections.formula:
E1T1 = E2T2
Efficiency Ratio = 1 / Time Ratio
sections.shortcut: • If A is n times as fast as B, then A:B efficiency is n:1 and time is 1:n.

sections.name: Group Work Formula
sections.theory: Work done by a group of people over a period of time.
sections.example:
Q: 12 men can complete a work in 16 days. How many men are required to complete the same work in 24 days?

Solution:
M1 = 12, D1 = 16
M2 = ?, D2 = 24
Using M1D1 = M2D2
12 × 16 = M2 × 24
M2 = (12 × 16) / 24 = 8 men

Answer: 8 men
sections.formula: M1D1H1 / W1 = M2D2H2 / W2 (where M=Men, D=Days, H=Hours, W=Work)
sections.shortcut: • If work is same, M1D1 = M2D2. If hours also given, M1D1H1 = M2D2H2.

sections.name: Work with Wages
sections.theory: Wages are distributed among workers in the ratio of the work done by them. If workers work for the same time, wages are in the ratio of their efficiencies.
sections.example:
Q: A and B can do a work in 6 and 8 days respectively. They undertook to do it for ₹3500. With the help of C, they finished it in 3 days. Find C's share.

Solution:
Total Work (LCM 6, 8, 3) = 24 units.
A's eff = 4 units/day. Total work by A = 4 × 3 = 12 units.
B's eff = 3 units/day. Total work by B = 3 × 3 = 9 units.
C's work = Total - (A+B) = 24 - (12+9) = 3 units.
Ratio of work A:B:C = 12:9:3 = 4:3:1
C's share = (1/8) × 3500 = ₹437.50

Answer: ₹437.50
sections.formula: Wage_A = [ Work_done_A / Total_Work ] × Total_Wage
sections.shortcut: • Always calculate the ratio of the actual work completed by each person.

sections.name: Pipes & Cisterns
sections.theory: Similar to Time and Work, but with negative work. Inlet pipes do positive work (fill), while Outlet pipes (leaks) do negative work (empty).
sections.example:
Q: Pipe A can fill a tank in 20 hours and Pipe B can empty it in 30 hours. If both are opened together, in how many hours will the tank be full?

Solution:
LCM of 20 and 30 is 60. Capacity = 60 units.
A's filling rate = 60 / 20 = +3 units/hr
B's emptying rate = 60 / 30 = -2 units/hr
Net rate = 3 - 2 = +1 unit/hr
Time to fill = 60 / 1 = 60 hours.

Answer: 60 hours
sections.formula:
1/T_net = 1/T1 + 1/T2 - 1/T_leak
Time = Capacity / Net Efficiency
sections.shortcut: • If a pipe fills in 'f' and leak empties in 'e', time to fill = (f × e) / (e - f).

sections.name: Basic TSD Concepts
sections.theory:
Distance = Speed × Time. This simple relationship governs all motion problems.

• Unit Conversion: Multiplying by 5/18 converts km/hr to m/s. Multiplying by 18/5 converts m/s to km/hr.
• If Distance is constant, Speed ∝ 1/Time.
• If Time is constant, Distance ∝ Speed.
sections.example:
Q: A car travels at 72 km/hr. Find its speed in m/s and the distance covered in 20 seconds.

Solution:
Speed in m/s = 72 × (5/18) = 4 × 5 = 20 m/s
Distance = Speed × Time = 20 × 20 = 400 meters.

Answer: 20 m/s, 400 m
sections.formula:
D = S × T
Speed = D/T, Time = D/S
km/hr → m/s: multiply by 5/18
sections.shortcut: • Remember 18 km/hr = 5 m/s. Multiples are easy: 36=10, 54=15, 72=20, 90=25.

sections.name: Relative Speed
sections.theory:
The speed of one object with respect to another while both are in motion.

• Same Direction: Relative Speed = S1 - S2 (Difference)
• Opposite Direction: Relative Speed = S1 + S2 (Sum)
sections.example:
Q: Two trains are 150 km apart. Train A starts at 8 AM at 50 km/hr towards B. Train B starts at 8 AM at 40 km/hr towards A. At what time will they meet?

Solution:
Relative Speed = 50 + 40 = 90 km/hr
Distance = 150 km
Time = 150 / 90 = 5/3 hours = 1 hour 40 minutes.
Meeting time = 8 AM + 1 hr 40 min = 9:40 AM.

Answer: 9:40 AM
sections.formula: Time to meet = Distance between them / Relative Speed
sections.shortcut: • If they start at different times, find the distance at the time when the second one starts first.

sections.name: Problems on Trains
sections.theory:
When a train crosses an object:

• Point Object (Pole/Man): Distance = Length of Train (L)
• Lengthy Object (Platform/Bridge): Distance = L + Length of Object (P)
• Crossing another Train: Distance = L1 + L2
sections.example:
Q: A 300m long train is running at 54 km/hr. How much time will it take to cross a 150m long platform?

Solution:
Speed = 54 × (5/18) = 15 m/s
Total Distance = 300 + 150 = 450 meters
Time = 450 / 15 = 30 seconds.

Answer: 30 seconds
sections.formula:
Time = (L + P) / Speed
Relative Time = (L1 + L2) / (Rel Speed)
sections.shortcut: • Always convert speed to m/s when lengths are in meters.

sections.name: Boats & Streams
sections.theory:
Motion in a moving medium (water).

• Speed of Boat in Still Water = u
• Speed of Stream = v
• Downstream Speed (D) = u + v (with the flow)
• Upstream Speed (U) = u - v (against the flow)
sections.example:
Q: A man can row 18 km/hr in still water. If the speed of the stream is 6 km/hr, find the time taken to row 48 km downstream.

Solution:
Downstream Speed (D) = 18 + 6 = 24 km/hr
Time = 48 / 24 = 2 hours.

Answer: 2 hours
sections.formula:
D = u + v, U = u - v
u = (D + U) / 2
v = (D - U) / 2
sections.shortcut: • If time taken upstream is 'n' times downstream, u = v × (n+1)/(n-1).

sections.name: Calculations on Races
sections.theory: Races involve 'Head start' (distance or time) and 'Dead heat' (finishing at same time).
sections.example:
Q: In a 1000m race, A beats B by 100m. In a 400m race, B beats C by 40m. By how many meters will A beat C in a 500m race?

Solution:
Ratio A:B = 1000 : 900 = 10 : 9
Ratio B:C = 400 : 360 = 10 : 9
Combined Ratio A:B:C = 100 : 90 : 81
In a 100m race, A beats C by 19m.
In a 500m race, A beats C by 19 × 5 = 95m.

Answer: 95m
sections.formula: Ratio of speeds = Ratio of distances covered in same time.
sections.shortcut: • 'A beats B by x meters' means when A is at the end, B is x meters behind.

sections.name: 2D Shapes - Area & Perimeter
sections.theory:
Mensuration of 2D shapes involves calculating the space inside (Area) and the length of the boundary (Perimeter).

• Triangle: Area = 1/2 × base × height OR √(s(s-a)(s-b)(s-c)) where s = (a+b+c)/2.
• Circle: Area = πr², Circumference = 2πr.
• Rectangle: Area = L × W, Perimeter = 2(L + W).
• Square: Area = a², Perimeter = 4a, Diagonal = a√2.
sections.example:
Q: The radius of a circular wheel is 70cm. How many revolutions will it make to cover a distance of 8.8 km?

Solution:
Radius (r) = 70 cm = 0.7 m
Distance to cover = 8.8 km = 8800 m
Circumference of wheel = 2 × (22/7) × 0.7 = 4.4 m
Number of revolutions = Total Distance / Circumference
Revolutions = 8800 / 4.4 = 2000.

Answer: 2000
sections.formula:
Triangle Area = √[s(s-a)(s-b)(s-c)]
Circle Circumference = 2πr
Rhombus Area = 1/2 × d1 × d2
sections.shortcut: • If each side of a figure is increased by x%, Area increases by [2x + x²/100]%.

sections.name: 3D Shapes - Volume & Surface Area
sections.theory:
Mensuration of 3D shapes involves calculating the capacity (Volume) and the area of the outer shell (Surface Area).

• Cube: Volume = a³, Total Surface Area (TSA) = 6a².
• Cuboid: Volume = L × W × H, TSA = 2(LW + WH + LH).
• Cylinder: Volume = πr²h, Curved Surface Area (CSA) = 2πrh, TSA = 2πr(r+h).
• Sphere: Volume = (4/3)πr³, TSA = 4πr².
• Cone: Volume = (1/3)πr²h, CSA = πrl where l = √(r²+h²).
sections.example:
Q: A cylindrical tank of radius 7m and height 10m is full of water. If all water is poured into a cubical tank of side 10m, will it overflow? If so, by how much?

Solution:
Volume of Cylinder = (22/7) × 7 × 7 × 10 = 1540 m³
Volume of Cube = 10 × 10 × 10 = 1000 m³
Yes, it will overflow.
Overflowing water = 1540 - 1000 = 540 m³.

Answer: Overflows by 540 m³
sections.formula:
Cylinder Volume = πr²h
Sphere Volume = 4/3 πr³
Cone Slant Height l = √(r² + h²)
sections.shortcut: • When a sphere is melted to form smaller spheres, n = (R/r)³.

sections.name: Lines & Angles Properties
sections.theory:
Basic properties of angles formed by intersecting and parallel lines.

• Complementary Angles: Sum = 90°
• Supplementary Angles: Sum = 180°
• Angles on a straight line = 180°, around a point = 360°
• Transversal of parallel lines: Alternate interior angles are equal; Corresponding angles are equal.
sections.example:
Q: An angle is 20° more than its supplement. Find the angle.

Solution:
Let the angle be x. Its supplement is 180 - x.
x = (180 - x) + 20
2x = 200
x = 100°

Answer: 100°
sections.formula:
Sum of interior angles of n-sided polygon = (n-2) × 180°
Each exterior angle of regular polygon = 360/n
sections.shortcut: • Sum of exterior angles of ANY polygon is always 360°.

sections.name: Properties of Triangles & Circles
sections.theory:
Key theorems and properties.

• Triangle: Sum of two sides > third side. Sum of angles = 180°.
• Pythagoras Theorem: a² + b² = c² (for right-angled triangles).
• Circle: Angle in a semi-circle is 90°. Tangent is perpendicular to the radius at the point of contact.
sections.example:
Q: The lengths of two sides of a right-angled triangle are 3cm and 4cm. Find the length of the hypotenuse.

Solution:
a² + b² = c²
3² + 4² = c²
9 + 16 = 25
c = √25 = 5cm.

Answer: 5cm
sections.formula:
Pythagoras: a² + b² = c²
Area of equilateral triangle = (√3 / 4) × a²

sections.name: Practical Mensuration & Costs
sections.theory:
Applying formulas to real-world costs.

• Fencing cost = Perimeter × Rate
• Painting/Plastering cost = Area × Rate
• Flooring cost = Floor Area × Rate
sections.example:
Q: Find the cost of fencing a circular garden of radius 21m at the rate of ₹10 per meter.

Solution:
Perimeter (Circumference) = 2 × (22/7) × 21
Perimeter = 2 × 22 × 3 = 132 m
Cost = 132 × 10 = ₹1,320

Answer: ₹1,320
sections.formula: Cost = (Relevant measure) × Rate
sections.shortcut: • For fencing, use perimeter. For painting/turfing, use area.

sections.name: Fundamental Counting Principles
sections.theory:
Counting principles form the base of P&C.

• Addition Principle (OR): If an event occurs in 'm' ways or 'n' ways (mutually exclusive), total = m + n.
• Multiplication Principle (AND): If an event occurs in 'm' ways followed by 'n' ways, total = m × n.
• Factorial (!): n! = n × (n-1) × ... × 1. (0! = 1)
sections.example:
Q: A person has 3 shirts and 4 trousers. In how many ways can he pick an outfit (1 shirt AND 1 trouser)?

Solution:
Ways to pick shirt = 3
Ways to pick trouser = 4
Total ways = 3 × 4 = 12.

Answer: 12
sections.shortcut: • Use AND for successive steps, OR for alternative options.

sections.name: Permutations (Arrangements)
sections.theory:
Permutation is an arrangement of items in a specific order. Order matters.

• nPr: Number of ways to arrange r items out of n.
• Repeated items: If an item repeats p times, q times, etc., divide by p!, q!.
• Circular Arrangement: (n-1)! ways.
sections.example:
Q: In how many ways can the letters of the word 'APPLE' be arranged?

Solution:
Total letters = 5
Repeated letter = P (2 times)
Ways = 5! / 2! = 120 / 2 = 60.

Answer: 60
sections.formula:
nPr = n! / (n - r)!
Circular = (n - 1)!
sections.shortcut: • If all items are distinct, it's just n!.

sections.name: Combinations (Selection)
sections.theory:
Combination is a selection of items where order does not matter.

• nCr: Number of ways to select r items out of n.
• Property: nCr = nC(n-r).
sections.example:
Q: In how many ways can a committee of 3 members be selected out of 10 people?

Solution:
10C3 = (10 × 9 × 8) / (3 × 2 × 1)
10C3 = 10 × 3 × 4 = 120.

Answer: 120
sections.formula:
nCr = n! / [r! (n - r)!]
nCr = nPr / r!
sections.shortcut: • Handshakes theorem: For n people, handshakes = nC2 = n(n-1)/2.

sections.name: Probability Basics
sections.theory:
Probability (P) is the likelihood of an event occurring.

• Sample Space (S): All possible outcomes.
• Event (E): Specific outcomes we are interested in.
• P(E) = n(E) / n(S). Range: 0 (impossible) to 1 (certain).
sections.example:
Q: If a coin is tossed twice, what is the probability of getting at least one head?

Solution:
S = {HH, HT, TH, TT}, n(S) = 4.
E (at least one H) = {HH, HT, TH}, n(E) = 3.
P(E) = 3/4.

Answer: 3/4
sections.formula:
P(E) = Number of favorable / Total possible
P(E) + P(not E) = 1
sections.shortcut: • 'At least' = 1 - P(None).

sections.name: Dice, Cards & Coins
sections.theory:
Standard scenarios in probability problems.

• Coins: n tosses → 2ⁿ total outcomes.
• Dice: n rolls → 6ⁿ total outcomes.
• Cards: 52 total. 4 suits (13 each), 2 colors (26 red, 26 black), 12 face cards (J, Q, K).
sections.example:
Q: Two dice are thrown simultaneously. What is the probability that the sum is 7?

Solution:
n(S) = 6 × 6 = 36.
Pairs giving sum 7: (1,6), (2,5), (3,4), (4,3), (5,2), (6,1). n(E) = 6.
P(E) = 6 / 36 = 1/6.

Answer: 1/6
sections.formula: P(A ∪ B) = P(A) + P(B) - P(A ∩ B)
sections.shortcut: • In 2 dice, the sum 7 is the most frequent (occurs 6 times).

sections.name: Clock Angles
sections.theory:
The dial of a clock is a circle (360°).

• Minute Hand: Moves 6° per minute (360° / 60 min).
• Hour Hand: Moves 0.5° per minute (30° / 60 min).
• Angle between hands: The difference between the positions of both hands.
sections.example:
Q: What is the angle between the hands of a clock at 3:30?

Solution:
H = 3, M = 30
Angle = |30H - (11/2)M|
Angle = |30(3) - (11/2)(30)|
Angle = |90 - 165| = 75°

Answer: 75°
sections.formula:
Angle = |30H - 5.5M|
Reflex Angle = 360° - Angle
sections.shortcut: • Overlapping hands: 0° angle. At 0°: M = (60/11) × H.

sections.name: Hands Overlapping & Opposite
sections.theory:
Relative positioning of the hands.

• Hands Overlap (0°): 22 times in 24 hours (once every hour except 11-1 and 5-7).
• Hands Opposite (180°): 22 times in 24 hours.
• Hands Right-Angled (90°): 44 times in 24 hours.
sections.example:
Q: At what time between 4 and 5 o'clock will the hands of a clock be together?

Solution:
H = 4, Angle = 0°
0 = |30(4) - 5.5M|
5.5M = 120
M = 120 / 5.5 = 240 / 11 = 21 9/11 minutes.
Time = 4:21 9/11.

Answer: 4:21 9/11
sections.formula: Time M = (2/11) × [30H ± Angle]
sections.shortcut: • To find together time, use M = (60/11) × H.

sections.name: Faulty Clocks
sections.theory: A clock that gains or loses time. If a clock covers more/less than 360° in its 'perceived' 12 hours.
sections.example:
Q: A clock is set right at 5 AM. The clock loses 16 minutes in 24 hours. What will be the true time when the clock indicates 10 PM on the 4th day?

Solution:
Time from 5 AM to 10 PM (4th day) = 89 hours.
In 24 hours (clock), true time = 24h 16m = 1456/60 h.
Wait, if it LOSES 16m in 24h, then 23h 44m of this clock = 24h of true time.
23h 44m = 356/15 hours.
True time = 89 × (24 / (356/15)) = 89 × 15 × 24 / 356 = 90 hours.
90 hours from 5 AM = 3 days and 18 hours = 11 PM.

Answer: 11 PM
sections.formula: True Time / Clock Time = True Interval / Clock Interval
sections.shortcut: • If a clock gains x min in 24h, True = Clock × 1440 / (1440 + x).

sections.name: Calendar Odd Days
sections.theory:
The core of calendar problems is 'Odd Days' - extra days above complete weeks.

• Ordinary Year (365 days) = 52 weeks + 1 Odd Day.
• Leap Year (366 days) = 52 weeks + 2 Odd Days.
• Leap Year check: Divisible by 4 (if century, divisible by 400).
sections.example:
Q: If today is Monday, what day will it be after 61 days?

Solution:
Odd days in 61 = 61 mod 7 = 5.
Monday + 5 days = Saturday.

Answer: Saturday
sections.formula: Odd days = Total days mod 7

sections.name: Finding Day of Week
sections.theory: Using codes for days and months to find the day for any historical or future date.
sections.example:
Q: What was the day on 15th August 1947?

Solution:
Upto 1600: 0 odd
1601 to 1900: 300 yrs = 1 odd
1901 to 1946: 46 yrs (11 leap, 35 ord) = 11*2 + 35*1 = 57 = 1 odd day.
Jan to 15 Aug 1947:
Jan(3)+Feb(0)+Mar(3)+Apr(2)+May(3)+Jun(2)+Jul(3)+Aug(1)=17 = 3 odd days.
Total Odd = 0 + 1 + 1 + 3 = 5 odd days.
5 odd days = Friday.

Answer: Friday
sections.formula: Day = (Day Code) of Total Odd Days
sections.shortcut: • 0=Sun, 1=Mon... 6=Sat.

sections.name: Definition & Laws
sections.theory:
Logarithm is the inverse operation to exponentiation. If a^x = N, then log_a(N) = x.

• Base (a): Must be positive and ≠ 1.
• Laws:
1. log(MN) = log M + log N
2. log(M/N) = log M - log N
3. log(M^p) = p log M
sections.example:
Q: Solve: log(2) + log(5).

Solution:
log(2) + log(5) = log(2 × 5) = log(10).
If base is 10, then log₁₀(10) = 1.

Answer: 1
sections.formula:
log(MN) = log M + log N
log(M/N) = log M - log N
log(M^p) = p log M
sections.shortcut: • log of 1 to any base is 0. log of base to itself is 1.

sections.name: Change of Base Theorem
sections.theory: Allows converting a logarithm from one base to another. This is crucial for using log tables or calculators which generally use base 10 or e.
sections.example:
Q: Evaluate log₈(16).

Solution:
Using change of base to base 2:
log₈(16) = log₂(16) / log₂(8)
16 = 2⁴, so log₂(16) = 4
8 = 2³, so log₂(8) = 3
Result = 4/3.

Answer: 4/3
sections.formula:
log_a(b) = log_c(b) / log_c(a)
log_a(b) = 1 / log_b(a)
sections.shortcut: • log_aⁿ(bᵐ) = (m/n) log_a(b).

sections.name: Logarithmic Equations
sections.theory: Equations where the variable is part of a log expression. To solve, convert the log form back to exponential form.
sections.example:
Q: Solve for x: log₂(x - 3) = 4.

Solution:
Convert to exponential form:
x - 3 = 2⁴
x - 3 = 16
x = 19.

Answer: 19
sections.formula: log_a(x) = y ⟹ x = a^y
sections.shortcut: • Always check if the solution makes the argument of the log positive.

sections.name: Number of Digits (Characteristic)
sections.theory:
The integer part of a common log (base 10) is called the Characteristic. It helps in finding the number of digits in a large power.

• Number of digits in aⁿ = Integer part of [n log₁₀(a)] + 1.
sections.example:
Q: Find the number of digits in 2⁶⁴. (Given log 2 = 0.3010)

Solution:
Value = 64 log 2 = 64 × 0.3010
Value = 19.264
Characteristic = 19.
Number of digits = 19 + 1 = 20.

Answer: 20
sections.formula: Digits = ⌊n log base₁₀⌋ + 1
sections.shortcut: • If log x = 3.45, x has 4 digits. If log x = 0.45, x has 1 digit.

sections.name: Tables
sections.theory:
Tables present data in rows and columns. They are the most precise way to show data but require careful reading of headers and units.

• Analysis: Look for totals, averages, and percentage changes between rows/columns.
sections.example:
Q: The table shows sales of 3 products (A, B, C) over 2 years. Year 1: A=100, B=150, C=200. Year 2: A=120, B=135, C=250. Find the total percentage growth in sales.

Solution:
Total Year 1 = 100 + 150 + 200 = 450.
Total Year 2 = 120 + 135 + 250 = 505.
Growth = 505 - 450 = 55.
% Growth = (55 / 450) × 100 = 12.22%.

Answer: 12.22%
sections.formula: % Growth = [ (New - Old) / Old ] × 100
sections.shortcut: • Use approximation: 55/450 is roughly 50/450 = 1/9 ≈ 11.11%. The answer is slightly more.

sections.name: Bar Charts
sections.theory:
Bar charts use vertical or horizontal bars to compare quantities between different categories.

• Types: Simple, Grouped, and Stacked bar charts.
sections.example:
Q: A bar chart shows revenue: Jan=₹10k, Feb=₹15k, Mar=₹20k. Find the average monthly revenue.

Solution:
Average = (10 + 15 + 20) / 3 = 45 / 3 = ₹15k.

Answer: ₹15k
sections.formula: Average = Sum / Number of items
sections.shortcut: • Visually look for the 'middle' bar or the balance point.

sections.name: Line Graphs
sections.theory: Line graphs are best for showing trends over time. The steeper the line, the faster the rate of change.
sections.example:
Q: A line graph shows speed from 0 to 10s. Speed increases linearly from 0 to 50 m/s. Find acceleration.

Solution:
Acceleration = Slope of speed-time graph.
Slope = (50 - 0) / (10 - 0) = 5 m/s².

Answer: 5 m/s²
sections.formula: Slope (Rate of change) = (y2 - y1) / (x2 - x1)
sections.shortcut: • A horizontal line means constant value (0 rate of change).

sections.name: Pie Charts
sections.theory:
Pie charts show the distribution of parts in a whole. The total is always 360° or 100%.

• Conversion: Value = (Angle / 360) × Total = (Percentage / 100) × Total.
sections.example:
Q: In a pie chart showing market share, Company A has a sector of 72°. If the total market is ₹1,000 crores, find Company A's revenue.

Solution:
Fraction = 72° / 360° = 1/5.
Revenue = 1/5 × 1,000 = ₹200 crores.

Answer: ₹200 crores
sections.formula:
1% = 3.6°
Value = (Central Angle / 360) × Total

sections.name: Blood Relations
sections.theory: Involves deciphering family relationships based on given clues. Use symbols for sexes (e.g., + for Male, - for Female) and tree structures for generations.
sections.example:
Q: Pointing to a man, a girl says, 'He is the son of the only daughter of my father's mother.' How is the man related to the girl?

Solution:
My father's mother = Grandmother.
Only daughter of grandmother = Father's sister = Aunt.
Son of aunt = Cousin.

Answer: Cousin
sections.formula: Horizontal line for siblings, Vertical for parent-child.
sections.shortcut: • Put yourself in the place of the person speaking to solve quickly.

sections.name: Coding & Decoding
sections.theory:
Messages are encoded using a specific logic (shifts, reversals, substitution). Identifying the pattern is key.

• Letter Coding: A becomes D (+3 shift).
• Number Coding: CAT = 3+1+20 = 24.
sections.example:
Q: In a certain code, 'KING' is written as 'PRMT'. How is 'QUEEN' written?

Solution:
Pattern: Opposite letters (K↔P, I↔R, N↔M, G↔T).
Q ↔ J, U ↔ F, E ↔ V, E ↔ V, N ↔ M.
Result: 'JFVVM'.

Answer: JFVVM
sections.formula:
A=1, B=2 ... Z=26
Opposite = 27 - Current position
sections.shortcut: • Memorize EJOTY (5, 10, 15, 20, 25) for quick letter positioning.

sections.name: Direction Sense
sections.theory:
Problems involving movements in 4 main directions (N, S, E, W) and 4 cardinal directions (NE, NW, SE, SW).

• Standard Mapping: North (Up), South (Down), East (Right), West (Left).
sections.example:
Q: A man walks 10m North, then turns Right and walks 7m, then turns Right and walks 10m. How far is he from the starting point?

Solution:
North 10m → Top
Right turn (East) 7m → Right
Right turn (South) 10m → Bottom
He is now 7m East from start.

Answer: 7 meters
sections.formula: Shortest distance = √(x² + y²) [Pythagoras]
sections.shortcut: • Always draw a small compass and track turns carefully.

sections.name: Syllogisms
sections.theory:
Logical arguments where a conclusion is drawn from two or more premises. Use Venn diagrams to test validity.

• Keywords: All, Some, No, Some Not.
sections.example:
Q: Statements: (1) All Cats are Dogs. (2) Some Dogs are Rats. Conclusion: Some Cats are Rats.

Solution:
Draw Circle A (Cats) inside Circle B (Dogs).
Draw Circle C (Rats) overlapping Circle B.
Is Circle C necessarily overlapping Circle A? No.
Conclusion is False.

Answer: False
sections.formula:
All A are B ⟹ A ⊆ B
Some A are B ⟹ A ∩ B ≠ ∅
sections.shortcut: • If statements are positive, a negative conclusion cannot follow.

sections.name: Cubes & Dice
sections.theory:
Visualizing unfolded cubes or identifying opposite faces on a die.

• Standard Dice: Sum of opposite faces = 7.
• Painted Cubes: n refers to side length ratio.
sections.example:
Q: Two positions of a dice are shown. Faces 1,2,3 visible in Pos 1. Faces 1,3,5 visible in Pos 2. What is opposite to 2?

Solution:
Faces 1 and 3 are common in both. The remaining faces in both (2 and 5) must be opposite.

Answer: 5
sections.formula:
Unpainted cubes = (n-2)³
Cubes with 1 face painted = 6(n-2)²
sections.shortcut: • In an open cube, alternate squares (horizontally or vertically) are opposite.

sections.name: Seating Arrangement
sections.theory:
Arranging items in a line (Linear) or circle (Circular).
